Exposed ternary metal active sites on mesoporous channels: A promising catalyst for low-temperature selective catalytic oxidization of phenol with H2O2 Shuying Gao a Fu Yang b ⁎ Xianfeng Liu a c Xu Hu a Changjian Song a Shijian Zhou a Yan Kong a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 210009, China State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering College of Chemical Engineering Nanjing Tech University Nanjing 210009 China 1State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 210009, China b School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu University of Science and Technology, Zhenjiang 212003, China School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering Jiangsu University of Science and Technology Zhenjiang 212003 China 2School of Environmental and Chemical Engineering, Jiangsu University of Science and Technology, Zhenjiang 212003, China c College of Environment Engineering, Nanjing Institute of Technology, Nanjing 210009, China College of Environment Engineering Nanjing Institute of Technology Nanjing 210009 China 3College of Environment Engineering, Nanjing Institute of Technology, Nanjing 210009, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A subtle catalyst design was provided with stably incorporated ternary catalytically active centers of Fe, Al and Mn into the skeleton of mesoporous silica. And the catalyst FAM-MS shows an optimal catalytic activity (22.8% conversion & 93.1% selectivity DHB) under optimal reaction conditions for selective oxidization of high concentration of phenol solution (ca. 30%) with H2O2 by virtue of the solubilizing effect of lauryl sodium sulfate in the reaction system. More importantly, the resulted catalyst reveals a durable catalytic activity with puny activity-loss (20% conversion & 90% selectivity DHB) during the fifteen recycling, which exhibits potential industrial application prospect. Multi-components-bearing mesoporous silica pays the way to the controlling of catalytic selective oxidation by virtue of the synergy of several functional active species in the catalyst, but still faces huge challenge in design and preparation of this functional catalyst. Herein, we rationally constructed a steady ternary-component catalyst (FAM-MS) by incorporating three kinds of catalytically active centers Fe, Al and Mn into the skeleton of mesoporous silica, which reveals a potential industrial application prospect. These resultant catalyst samples were investigated thoroughly by various means, which include XRD, HRTEM, N2-isotherms, UV–vis, and XPS. The present results indicated that the FAM-MS catalyst affords narrow pore size distribution (2.71 nm), 2D hexagonal mesostructure and huge specific surface area (918 m2·g−1) which accordingly contributes to a capacious catalytic reaction space. In addition, the synergy of tri-active components shows greater ability to improve the selectivity of DHB, compared to single-active component and dual-active components ones. As a result, the catalyst FAM-MS shows an optimal catalytic activity (22.8% conversion & 93.1% selectivity DHB) under the optimal reaction conditions for selective oxidization of high concentration of phenol solution (ca. 30%) with H2O2 by virtue of the solubilizing effect of lauryl sodium sulfate in the reaction system. More importantly, the resulted catalyst reveals a durable catalytic activity with puny activity-loss (20% conversion & 90% selectivity DHB) during the fifteen recycling, which exhibits potential industrial application prospect. Keywords Mesoporous Silicon dioxide Tri-active components Phenol Hydroxylation High concentration Durable catalytic activity 1 Introduction Periodic mesoporous silicon dioxide have been extensively studied and considered as a potential catalytic support material, owing to the huge specific surface area, regular pore structure (2–10 nm) and controllable physiochemical properties [1]. Especially for catalytic reactions of aromatic hydrocarbons, the molecular dynamic diameter usually > 0.6 nm, the mesoporous structure would lead to good flow-through diffusion pathways for the reactants and products [2,3]. In addition, the highly specific surface area could provide more foothold for accommodating catalytic active centers. However, pure mesoporous silica materials usually exhibit poor catalytic performance for various reaction due to the lack of catalytic active center. Recent years, great efforts have been made to address these inherent weaknesses by introducing different kinds of active centers to the surface or skeleton of the pure mesoporous silica materials [1,4]. Dihydroxybenzene (DHB), as a kind of important intermediates in organic synthesis, have been used extensively in various fields, such as spices, dyes, polymerization inhibitor, developer, pharmaceuticals, and rubber. While the traditional industrial production process of DHB usually needs multi-steps, large amounts of solvent and high energy of consumption, which would bring a great burden to the natural environment. Recently, direct selective oxidation of phenol with green oxidants of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and solvent water (H2O) provide a newly-prospective synthetic route [5–9]. For decades, various types of heterogeneous catalysts had been widely developed for this reaction, such as mesoporous metal oxides [10,11], titanium-silicon molecular sieve (TS-1) [12], and metal complexes [13–15]. Even some reported catalysts have exhibited considerable catalytic results, but still suffer from some severe issues such as reaction temperature, reaction solvent or manufacturing cost of the catalyst. Mesoporous silica, especially for Fe-based those, exhibits huge potential owing to the low reaction temperature and environmentally-friend reaction system [16–20]. But most single-active component modified mesoporous silica failed to exhibit desirable catalytic activity in terms of the selectivity of DHB. For example, Fu et al. [21] successful prepared single-active component Cu modified MCM-41 by a facilely method and applied it as a catalyst for selective oxidation of phenol under mild condition. As a result, the catalyst exhibited the optimal catalytic activity (38% conversion & 65% selectivity DHB). As such, Wang and Kong et al. [22] reported a series of Fe doped MCM-41 materials, and the catalyst exhibited great catalytic phenol conversion 25.3%. However, the best selectivity of DHB only reach 78.4%. Recent years, various studies have shown that multi-components-bearing mesoporous silica pays the way to the controlling of catalytic selective oxidation by virtue of the synergy of several functional active species in the catalyst [23,24]. For instance, Parida et al. [25] found that the catalytic performance of single-active component (Cu) modified mesoporous silica (Cu-MCM-41) could be highly improved for direct hydroxylation of phenol, after introducing second active centers of Al species into the framework. Zhang et al. [26] found that the dual-component active centers of Fe and Ce species could generate a strong synergistic effect on the selective oxidation of phenol, which exists in the framework of SBA-15. However, the construction and design of functional active species on the mesoporous silica is still difficult owing to the matching and special interaction of several metals. Hence, ternary-component active centers of Fe, Al, and Mn co-modified mesoporous silica heterogeneous catalyst FAM-MS was designed and synthesized by a facile hydrothermal method (Scheme 1 ) for direct hydroxylation of phenol to DHB. In addition, we developed sodium dodecyl as a solubilizer to enhance the solubility of phenol under water condition. Both of the structural characteristics and the chemical status of Fe, Al, Mn species in catalyst had been investigated in detail by various characterization methods. Furthermore, catalytic influence factors including catalyst dosage, reaction temperature, reaction time, surfactant and the durable catalytic performance were meticulously examined to identify the optimal reaction conditions under mild reaction condition. Finally, the possible selective oxidation mechanism was proposed accordingly. 2 Experiment 2.1 Preparation of ternary complex heterogeneous catalyst FAM-MS The ternary catalyst was prepared referring to our previously work and a little modify [27]. Firstly, 3.6 g CTAB and 11.4 g Na2SiO3·9H2O were dissolved in 100 mL deionized water to form a clear solutions A. Controlled stoichiometric of mental sources (Fe, Mn and Al) were dissolved in 20  mL deionized water to form solutions B. Then, after blended the solutions A and B, the results mixture were stirred 2 h. A certain amount of TMAOH solution (25%) was dropped into the above-mixed solution (molar rate of CTAB: Si: Fe: Al: Mn = 25: 100: 2: 0.5: 0.5). After stirring for 0.5 h, the pH of the mixed solutions was controlled at 11 with dilute sulfuric acid solutions (1 M), and stirred an additional 30 min. At last, the obtained mixed solutions were transferred to the steel autoclave and heated to 100 °C for 5 days. The resulting product were centrifuged, washed with ethanol and dried at 60 °C for 12 h. Finally, the product were calcined at 550 °C for 4 h under air condition to remove the surfactants. The calcined samples were denoted as FAM-MS. 2.2 Synthesis of comparative catalysts Several comparative catalysts were further prepared were prepared based on the above similar synthesis method. For example, the sample MS and F-MS were prepared without metal source and with the single iron metal source (Fe: Si = 2:100). The double metal modified mesoporous silica were prepared with bimetallic component Fe and Al (Fe: Al: Si = 2:0.5:100, 2:1:100, denoted as FA-MS, F2A-MS) or Fe and Mn (Fe: Mn: Si = 2:0.5:100, 2:1:100, denoted as FM-MS, F2M-MS). The ternary metal modified mesoporous silica were prepared with three component Fe, Al and Mn (Fe: Al: Mn: Si = 2:0.2:0.2:100, 2:0.5:0.5:100 and 2:1:1:100 denoted as F0.5A0.5M-MS, FAM-MS, F2A2M-MS). The samples containing ternary metal oxides MnFeAlOx/MCM-41 and MnFeOx/Al-MCM-41 were synthesized by impregnation method (the molar rate of Si: Fe: Al: Mn = 100: 2: 0.5: 0.5). And the Ti-MCM-41 with Ti: Si ratio of 2: 100 was synthesized according to a published procedure [28]. TS-1 molecular sieves directly purchased from Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.3 Characterizations The mesoporous structure of different samples were examined with a Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, Smartlab TM 9 KW, λ =0.154178 nm). A High-resolution TEM (JEM-2010 EX, 200 kV) were used to analyze the mesoporous structure and element mapping of samples. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were employed with Micrometrics ASAP 2020 instrument at 77 K to obtain meso-porosity information. The UV–vis Diffused Reflection spectra of different samples were collected by Perkin-Elmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer (200 nm – 800 nm). And the dried BaSO4 were used as reference substance. The information of active center on the samples surface was characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ULVAC-PHI). All banding value were calibrated with the C1 s peak (284.6 eV). The iron, aluminum and manganous contents of different samples were collected by Inductively Coupling Plasma emission spectrometer (PerkinElmer, Waltham, MA, USA). The ·OH-trapping measurements were detected by Electron spin resonance spectra (ESR, Brucker ER 200D-SR) at room temperature. The MAS NMR experiments were measured by BruckerAvanceIII spectrometers (Bruker,Germany), with a 4 mm probe. The frequencies used were 78.21 MHz for 27Al and 59.63 MHz for 29Si and the MAS rates were 10 kHz and 5 kHz, respectively. The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of adsorbed pyridine were recorded using a Nicolet-510 P apparatus. The Ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was measured in a fixed-bed reactor of BEL Catal I. 2.4 Catalysis performance test This reaction was conducted in a 30 mL flask, firstly, deionized water (10 mL), phenol (4.29 g), sodium dodecyl sulfate (0.36 g) and catalyst (50 mg) were homogeneous mixed. Subsequently, 1.6 mL H2O2 were dropped into the flask, and the reaction solution was maintained at certain temperature and reacted for a desirable time. Finally, the resulted reaction solution was centrifugation and diluted with the water for the HPLC analysis (Shanghai Wufeng Scientific Instruments Co., Ltd. China), which equipped with an SB-C18 column and an ultraviolet detector (λ = 265 nm). The composition of the mobile phase were mixture of methanol/water (30/70, V/V) and the flow rate was set at 1.0 mL·min−1. The calculated catalytic results were based on the external standard method. When the reaction finished, the used catalysts were separated from the reaction solution by centrifugation, then washed with ethanol and dried at 70 °C. After these treatments, this used catalysts were re-evaluated by selective oxidation of phenol. In the fifth cycle, additional calcined method was employed to address the used catalysts. And the corresponding samples were denoted as FAM-MS-n (n represent the recycle times). At finally, the catalyst was recycled 15 times in total. 2.5 ·OH-trapping measurements The ESR spectra were conducted at room temperature referring to a previous report [29]. Typically, the catalyst sample (30 mg), H2O2 (45 μL) DMPO (30 μL) were homogeneous mixed, and then added into the ESR tube. Subsequently, this tube was inserted into the instrument to detect the existence of ·OH. 2.6 Characterization of acid properties Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of adsorbed pyridine were collected using a Nicolet-510 P apparatus. The samples were pressed into thin wafers and placed in a Pyrex glass cell equipped with CaF2 windows. The samples were pretreated in situ at 300 °C for 1 h under vacuum (10-6 Torr) and then cooled to room temperature. Afterward, the pyridine was passed over the sample for 30 min and the pyridine adsorption spectra were recorded after desorption at 150 °C for 1 h. Ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was measured in a fixed-bed reactor of BEL Catal II under a flow of NH3/Ar and a heating rate of 10 °C /min from 50 to 700 °C. The pretreatment was carried out at a flow rate of 30 mL/min at 300 °C for 1 h in argon, and the uptake amount of NH3 was recorded. 3 Results 3.1 The mesostructual properties of resultant samples The mesostructure of different samples were firstly investigated by low-angle XRD method and correspond information were illustrated in Fig. 1 . As shown in Fig. 1 (a), all samples exhibit a well-resolved diffraction peak (100) at about 2.3° tighter with two weak diffraction peaks (110) and (200), which indicates the catalyst maintain a highly-ordered hexagonal structure (p6mm) [30], even three metal elements are encapsulated into the mesoporous silica framework. Additionally, we could observe the main diffraction peak (100) of sample F-MS, FA-MS, FM-MS, and FAM-MS shifts to the lower angle region compared with pure MS, which suggests the increment of the unit cell parameter (a0) after introducing the metal element. This phenomenon could be attributed to the Si cation existed in the skeleton of mesoporous silica have been partial replaced by the metal species of Fe, Al, and Mn [31]. For the wide-angle XRD patterns of different samples in Fig. 1 (b), no any obvious observable diffraction peak of iron oxide, aluminum oxide, and manganese oxide is detected in their respective diffraction curves, indicating the extreme-dispersion of various metal oxides or possible incorporation of the isolative atomic Fe, Al and Mn species in the framework of mesoporous matrix. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were employed to obtain more mesoporous information, and corresponding detailed structural parameters date were listed in Table 1 . As shown in Fig. 2 (a), all samples shows a similar type IV curve, and a sharp degree steep could be observed at low relative pressure area (P/P0 , 0.25–0.35), which indicates that the samples of F-MS, FA-MS, FM-MS, and FAM-MS would maintain the excellent ordered mesoporous structure even after introducing multi-metal species [4,32]. The spacing of the adsorption and desorption isotherms exhibit an increasing trend at high relative pressure area (P/P0 , 0.5-0.9) for samples F-MS, FA-MS, FM-MS, and FAM-MS, which attributes to the additional void defective pores appeared in the catalyst after introducing heteroatom metal. And corresponding direct comparative TEM results derived from pure mesoporous MS (Figure S1a) and FAM-MS (Figure S1b) could be observed and identified. Especially for the metal heteroatoms incorporated into the mesoporous matrix, the sample FAM-MS exhibits numerous disordered pores (ca. 25˜50 nm). Relates to the generation of hysteresis loop, thereby giving rise to the obvious separation of absorption and desorption isotherms at high pressure, compared with the pure MS. This phenomenon is also observed in some reported literatures [33,34], these type-H4 hysteresis loop between the approximately relative pressures of P/P0  = 0.4–1.0 involves the appearance of some void defects in the mesoporous silica. Furthermore, for sample F-MS, FA-MS, FM-MS, and FAM-MS, the inflection point of step shifts to the higher relative pressure compared with pure MS. which indicate the increase of the average pore size after introduced more metals species [35]. Consider with the similar pore size distributions appear at ca 2.65 nm (Fig. 2 b), the exist of additional large secondary mesopores can be indicated. As shown in Fig. 2 (b), the pore size distributions of different samples from 2 nm to 60 nm, calculated from the BJH model, a weak peak at ca 35 nm could be observed for samples F-MS, FA-MS, FM-MS, and FAM-MS, which further indicates the formation of void defects(large secondary mesopores) on the prepared process. And this large mesopores shift to larger pore size area with the introduction of heteroatoms. As shown in Table 1, we could observe that the SBET and pore volume just exhibit a slight variation (935 m2 g−1 to 895 m2 g−1 and 0.94 cm3 g−1 to 0.89 cm3 g−1) after introducing metal species into the skeleton of mesoporous silica. While the Al and Mn species are introduced into the framework, the surface area and pore volume appeared slightly increasing trend compared to single Fe species modified one, which indicates the Al and Mn species are conducive to improve the structural regularity of the mesoporous structure through the assistance of iron species. And the pore diameter increase from 2.61 nm to 2.71 nm, calculated from the BJH model, which would benefit to the transfer of reactants. Furthermore, we found the wall thickness derived from the BET and XRD results also increase from 1.85 nm to 1.93 nm with the metal species introduces, which could be beneficial to improve the hydrothermal stability, subsequently results in an improvement of catalyst stability. The mesostructure of FAM-MS was further examined by HRTEM and element mapping techniques. As shown in Fig. 3 (a, b), a typical dense honeycomb structure in the axial direction of the channel could be observed. When viewing in the radial direction of the channel (Fig. 3 c), the pores are presented to be arranged in patches composed of regular rows. Also, the Fast Fourier Transform patterns demonstrate the typical hexagonal structure. This is entirely consistent with the low-angle XRD results. Furthermore, there is no any observable aggregated particle neither inside nor outside of the pore channels, which is further identified by the HAADF image (Fig. 3d) since no bright spots can be observed. Meanwhile, element mapping by STEM confirmed that the Fe, Al, Mn species are uniformly dispersed in the selected mesoporous silica matrix rather than the partial aggregation, which conduces to stabilize the active center in the long-term reuse process. Based on the previous pore size results, the wall thickness increased to 1.93 nm from 1.85 nm after the introduced metal species, which conduces to stabilize the mesoporous structure. Such unique features render these catalyst FAM-MS show greater catalytic stability. Meanwhile, the high dispersion of the ternary catalytically active centers in the skeleton of mesoporous silica pore walls, creating the chance for ternary metal species synergistic control the production rate of H2O2/HO· in reaction space. Thus, further depth discussion would be presented in the following section. 3.2 Characterization of the state of iron, aluminum and manganese species The coordination state of Fe, Al and Mn species in the samples were explored by diffuse reflection UV–vis spectra [36]. As shown in Fig. 4 , all the samples show a wide-ranges absorption band center at about 220 nm, which attributes to the characteristic absorption peak of mesoporous silica framework [37,38]. While, the samples of F–MS, FA–MS, FM–MS and FAM–MS showed another absorption band centered at about 254 nm, due to low energy charge-transfer transitions between oxygen and metal ion (O2−→Fe, Al and Mn) [39–41]. This is typical phenomenon for metal substituted place of silicon atoms in the skeleton of mesoporous silica with a tetrahedral environment. Furthermore, there is no observed absorption band at high energy range (400 nm–800 nm), which represent the bulk-like metal oxide species with octahedral coordination [42]. This analysis result reveals that most metal species were incorporated into silica framework with its environment in the tetrahedral coordination. Further precise information about the states of metal coordination of sample FAM-MS could be obtained from XPS data and corresponding information were showed in Fig. 5 . The surface atom content ratio of Fe, Al, and Mn to Si is 1.94 mol %, 0.49 mol %, and 0.49 mol %, respectively, which are determined by the XPS method. This closely corresponded to the ICP results (Fe, Al, and Mn to Si is 1.93 mol %, 0.49 mol %, and 0.50 mol %, Table S1) for sample FAM-MS and the theoretical amounts that were added (see experiment section), which suggests the uniform distribution of Fe, Al and Mn species. The Si 2p (Fig. 5d) peak at 103.4 eV of sample FAM-MS attribute to the framework –O–Si–O– chains, which was lower than the Si 2p peak of sample MS (103.8 eV). This is consistent with our previous analysis, the silicon atoms could be replaced by the Fe, Al and Mn atoms and thus changed the electron density of the molecular sieve framework [43]. As for the Fe 2p spectrum (Fig. 5a), two main peaks attribute to Fe 2p1/2 (peak at 725.7 eV) and Fe 2p3/2 (peak at 712.1 eV) are observed, with energy splitting of 13.6 eV, which is suggestive of Fe3+ species exist in the framework of silica. Furthermore, the binding energy of Fe 2p3/2 obtained here is much higher than that of bulk Fe2O3 (from 710.6 to 711.2 eV) [44], which is attributed to the electron delocalization between Fe and the –O–Si–O– chains existed in the framework of mesoporous silica (MS) [45], as a result of electron from Fe to the –O–Si–O– chains [43]. This results indicate that the iron atoms had been successful incorporated into the framework of mesoporous silica. As for the Mn 2p spectrum (Fig. 5b), two main fitting XPS peak could be observed, which attributed to Mn 2p1/2 (peak at 654.3 eV) and Mn (peak at 642.4 eV), respectively. This is suggestive of Mn4+ species exist in the framework of silica species [46]. Additionally, as for the phenomenon of Fe 2p spectrum, the binding energy of Mn 2p3/2 shifts to a higher value compared to normal manganese oxides, which indicated the formation of framework −Si−O–Mn− band [47]. The O 1s spectrum (Fig. 5e) was fitted to two peaks at 532.4 eV and 532.8 eV based on the formed different environment, which is assigned to oxygen atoms in −Si–O–M− (Fe, Al, Mn) and −Si–O–Si− groups, respectively [48]. Combine the results of UV–vis spectra analysis of active center, we propose the interaction of metal species in the framework with tetrahedral coordination environment. In addition, a hypothetical structure is proposed and illustrated in Scheme 2 . The groups of −Si–O–Fe− could be surrounded by −Si−O–Mn− and −Si−O–Al− band, such structural features would generate a synergistic effect on increased electron cloud density of the main catalytic activity center Fe, with the assistance of Mn. However, the H2O2 is more prone to be activated by the active metal centers whit low electron density. Hence, the activation rate of H2O2/HO· would be suppressed, which would lead to the high selectivity of DHB. And their corresponding enhanced catalyze test results would be discussed in the following section. To further confirm the formation of heteroatom-substituted mesoporous materials (Fe, Al and Mn), also take FAM-MS for example, the result of 29Si MAS NMR AND 27Al MAS NMR spectrum were shown in Fig. 6 . As for the 29Si MAS NMR of the calcined FAM-MS sample in Fig. 6 (a), the sample FAM-MS exhibit three main signals with detectable maxima at 91 ppm, 100 ppm, and 110 ppm corresponding to Si-(-O-Si-)x(-O-M)(4-x) framework units, where M represents H or metal atom (Fe, Al and Mn), x = 2 (Q2), x = 3 (Q3) and x = 4 (Q4), [33,49,50]. The presence of Q4 group indicating that the local arrangement of Si-O-Si bonds in the mesoporous silica pore walls. Furthermore, the Q3 group could be related to silicon with Si(SiO)3OH structure or with the Si(SiO3)M, structure, where M is a metal (M = Fe, Al and Mn), respectively. And the Q2 group could be attributed to silicon with Si(SiO)2OH2 structure or with the Si(SiO2)M2 structure, respectively. These presence of Q3 and Q2 groups verify the successful incorporation of metal into the mesoporous silica framework [51]. Note that the structure of the FAM-MS network is rather irregular and has a wide range of M–O–Si angles (M represents the metal atom), so that the systematic peak shift to lower field with each metal substitution also exhibited a broad a broad signal [33,49]. And such similar phenomenon could also be observed by the previous report [51–53], when single-metal or multi-metal components species are incorporated into the framework of porous silica materials. Furthermore, the 27Al MAS NMR measurement was employed to detect the specific status of Al in the mesoporous silica. As shown in Fig. 6 (b), only one peak could be observed at chemical shift of 55 ppm which is related to the tetrahedrally coordinated Al (framework alumina) [54]. And no any signal at 0 ppm belonging to the octahedrally coordinated Al could be detected, which suggests that all of the Al species are successfully incorporated into the framework of the resulted samples FAM-MS. Combining with the previous analysis results, hence, we proposed the Fe, Al and Mn species were successful incorporated into the framework of mesoporous silica. 3.3 Characterization of acid properties of different samples To investigate the surface acid properties, FTIR of pyridine adsorbed and NH3-TPD were measured, respectively. Firstly, FTIR of pyridine adsorbed were employed to investigate the surface acid properties. To be well known, the pristine silica material lacks of acidity. As for sample FMS in Fig. 7 (b), the FTIR spectra of pyridine adsorbed exhibited two weak vibration bands at 1445 and 1541 cm−1 corresponding to the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites [55], respectively, indicated weak acidity could be generated by the framework Fe [56,57]. Furthermore, when the Al species were incorporated into the framework of mesoporous silica, as for samples of FAMS and FAM-MS, the intensity of vibration bands at 1445 and 1541 cm−1 were obviously enhanced, indicating the concertation of surface acid sites were greatly increased and most of the acid sites are existed as Lewis acid sites. The strength of surface acidity is studied by NH3-TPD and the result is illustrated in Fig. 7 (b). As shown in Fig. 7 (b), in the case of F-MS, a weaker and broader desorption peak could be observed at around 150 °C, which could be attributed to the Fe atoms successful incorporated in the MS framework with its environment in the tetrahedral coordination [57]. After introducing the Al into the framework, for samples FA-MS and FAM-MS, a stronger desorption peak around 160 °C is obtained, indicating more acidic sites are generated on the catalyst surface. Combine with the previous FTIR of pyridine adsorbed analysis, it is reasonable to conclude that the acidic sites of FAM-MS should be attributed to the introducing procedure of Al species [54]. 3.4 Catalytic test Firstly, we investigated the influence of the amount of solubilizer surfactant SDS on the reaction activity, aiming at enhancing the solubility of phenol for overcoming the limitation of low concentration reaction. As shown in Table 2 , the phenol conversion decreases when the selectivity of DHB increases slightly with the increase of SDS usage (entry 1–2). And a similar phenomenon was also observed for low phenol concentration reaction from entry 4–5. Because excessive surfactant in the reaction system will reduce the chance of phenol being attacked by hydroxyl active radical [58]. However, the role of solubilizer is critical for the reaction, when the surfactant is absent, the catalyst FAM-MS exhibits poor catalytic activity (entry 3, 11.7% conversion & 87.3% selectivity DHB), which is attributed to the high content of phenol failing to be dissolved in an aqueous solution completely. In addition, the catalytic activity of FAM-MS decreases slightly only from 25.3% to 22.8% in conversion, and from 95.5% to 93.1% in selectivity despite a higher reactant concentration (entry 1& 4), which indicates a potential application prospect, compared with that reaction involving low phenol concentration under the similar condition. Then, the effect of the reaction conditions were investigated in detail for the catalytic performance of selective oxidation of phenol, which included temperature, catalyst dosage, molar ratios of phenol/H2O2 and reaction time on the phenol, and corresponding test results were showed in Fig. 8 . As shown in Fig. 8 (a), we could observe that the phenol conversion increased slightly but the selectivity of DHB could be maintained above 93% with the increased temperature (15 °C – 25 °C). While, once the temperature exceeded 25 °C, the selectivity of DHB (catechol + hydroquinone, CAT + HQ) decrease significantly (from 93.1%–86.8%). This is attributed to the high temperature could increase the activation rate of H2O2, subsequently leading to the over-oxidation of DHB, in turn. According to the above experimental results, 25 °C was chosen as the optimal reaction temperature. Also, ss shown in Fig. 8 (b), the effect of amount of catalyst reveals the catalytic conversion can be sharply enhanced accompanied with high selectivity with the increased amount of catalyst (30 mg–50 mg). However, note that the selectivity of DHB decreased obviously when the dosage of catalyst exceed 50 mg, which verifies 50 mg seems to be optimal amount of catalyst. The effects of the molar ratios of H2O2/phenol on the hydroxylation of phenol is shown in Fig. 8 (c). The phenol conversion increases from 13.6% to 22.8%, the selectivity of DHB decreases slightly, with H2O2/phenol (molar ratio) increase from 1:5 to 1:3, and the CAT/HQ ratio shows no obvious change. But with the further addition of the amount of H2O2 (exceed 1:3), the selectivity of DHB goes down from 93.1% to 78.3% and CAT/HQ ratio falls off from 1.82 to 1.25. The above results suggest that excessive H2O2 would lead to a high concentration of ·OH, which would result in over oxidation of the final product. Therefore, 1:3 should be the best molar ratio of H2O2/phenol. The effect of reaction time for the reaction of selective oxidation of phenol is described in Fig. 8 (d). While in the last period of reaction ranging from 0.5 h to 2 h, the reaction conversion rate shows the slowly-increased trend and the selectivity of DHB is higher and can be maintained at 93.1% until 2 h. But as the reaction continues, the selectivity of DHB drops off due to the over-oxidation of DHB, while the chance to generating by-products was increasing, too. Considering the yield of phenol, indicating the optimal reaction time is 2 h. In addition, according to the suggestion of the reviewer, we also test the effect of other organic solvents on the catalytic effect. As shown in Table S2, when acetone, acetonitrile or methanol was used as solvents, the hydroxylation of phenol reaction did not instantly occur, which agrees with other reports [59]. But the catalytic activity involving water as reaction solvent is obtained in the present condition. This may be attributed to that phenol and H2O2 rapidly reach the active sites in water. The other reason is the active species, such as ·OH produced in organic solvents may react with them rather than the phenol. Furthermore, there is no doubt that water is the most ideal solvent by virtues of safety, cheap, and environmentally friendly for the liquid phase oxidation reaction. Taken together, therefore, the water were chosen as the reaction solvent. We also explored the effect of ratios of Si/Al/Mn/Fe on the catalytic performance, and corresponding catalytic results were illustrated in Table S3. As a results, the FAM-MS exhibited the best catalytic activity (22.8% conversion & 93.1% selectivity DHB). And we also tested the catalytic performance of commercial catalyst TS-1 and Ti-MCM-41 to as a contrast. As shown in Table 3 , the pure MS doesn’t show any activity and the monometal F-MS exhibited poor catalytic selectivity (77.2%) with inferior utilization efficiency of H2O2 (59.1%), this is much lower than the catalytic activity of TS-1 and Ti-MCM-41 in term of selectivity and utilization efficiency of H2O2. However, when the Ti are employed as active center, the reaction should be conducted in the acetone and surfer a long reaction time. According to our previous report, Fe species are the great active sites for the reaction of selective oxidation of phenol, but single Fe active center has poor performance on control selectivity of DHB [60], which due to the existed over-oxidation of dihydroxybenzene. To further improve its selectivity of DHB, the Al and Mn are proposed and utilized as the catalytic promoters. For sample FM-MS, the catalytic selectivity and utilization efficiency of H2O2 have great improvement (89.8% and 71.5%, respectively), while the conversion rate has decreased by about 5 points. There could exist a strong interaction between Fe and Mn species in the catalyst of FM-MS, which could have a synergic effect on controlling the activation rate of H2O2/HO·, subsequently, this character would lead to high selectivity by preventing the occurrence of excessive oxidation. Combined with the previous meso-structural properties and state of active center analysis results, this character is attributed to the changed electron cloud density of catalytic activity center Fe would be adjusted with the assistance of Mn species. Also, from previous reports, the silica materials could be more hydrophilic by the incorporation of metal species, thus could enhance the chemisorption of phenol and hydrogen peroxide on the active sites. But owing to polarity factor and relatively smaller size of hydroxyl radicals, the adsorption of H2O2 is preferential than phenol molecules on the same active site, leaving more phenol in the un-adsorbed state. By this situation, the reaction between free phenol and hydroxyl radicals would yield more selective dihydroxybenzene. For FAMS samples, the increase in the yield of DHB and benzoquinone could be due to the acidic active center provided by Al, which is beneficial to stabilize the presence of hydroxyl groups [61,62]. According to the previous report [62], the acid groups existed on the surface of mesoporous silicon might enable the formation of H+ concentrated region which can significantly suppress the decomposition of H2O2 into H2O and O2. Interesting, both H2O2 utilization and phenol conversion of sample FAMS had been improved, due to more H2O2 would be utilized to reacted phenol, this is consistent with the previous assumption. Also, from previous reports [26], the hydrophilia of mesoporous silica materials would be enhanced by incorporated metal species into the framework, which would leading to the enhancement of chemisorption of phenol and hydrogen peroxide. In addition, from the previous meso-structural properties results, the pore diameter increased from 2.61 nm to 2.71 nm, which would benefit to the transfer of reactants. Therefore, the catalysts activity of FMS could be greater improved with the assistance of Al and Mn species. As a result., the catalyst FAM-MS shows an optimal catalytic activity (22.8% conversion & 93.1% selectivity DHB) It was widely recognized that the hydroxylation of phenol by H2O2 over Fe3+ based catalysts is through a radical mechanism [20,63,64]. We adopted the DMPO–ESR spectroscopy experiment to detect ·OH of catalyst FAM-MS. As shown in Fig. 9 , an ESR signal assigned to DMPO−OH (with an intensity ratio of 1:2:2:1) was obtained, indicating the generation of ·OH during the catalytic process. We adopted the DMPO–ESR spectroscopy experiment to detect ·OH of catalyst FAM-MS. As shown in Fig. 9, an ESR signal assigned to DMPO−OH was obtained, indicating the generation of ·OH during the catalytic process. Also, the XPS measurement were employed to detect the changes of valence state of the Fe and Mn species of samples FAM-MS after reaction. All binding energy values were calibrated with the C1 s peak (284.6 eV). As shown in Fig. 10 (a), two main peaks attributed to Fe2p1/2 (peak at 725.7 eV) and Fe2p3/2 (peak at 712.1 eV) are observed, with energy splitting of 13.6 eV, which is suggestive of Fe3+ species exist in the framework of silica [65]. Nevertheless, the deconvolution of Fe2p3/2 peak shows two typical peaks corresponding to Fe3+ and Fe2+ oxidation states [44,66]. Similar behavior was reported for Fe based catalyst after the catalytic oxidation process [67]. The generation of Fe2+ could be attributed to the interaction of Fe active species, phenol and hydrogen peroxide yielding HO· species via a Fe(III)/Fe(II) redox pair. However, as for the Mn 2p spectrum (Fig. 10b), two main fitting XPS peak could be observed, which attributed to Mn 2p1/2 (peak at 654.3 eV) and Mn 2p3/2 (peak at 642.4 eV), respectively, which is suggestive of Mn4+ species existed in the framework of mesoporous silica [47]. This is consistent with the valence state of the involved manganese before the reaction. Therefore, the Fe3+ species should be the main active center and Fe2+ would be generated after the reaction cycle, but the valence state of the Mn4+ species did not change, indicating its feeble reaction participation in the reaction process. Accordingly, the reaction pathway of phenol hydroxylation over FAM-MS samples were proposed, which is illustrated in Scheme 2. Firstly, there would generate HO· active species from hydrogen peroxide by a Fe3+ to Fe2+ redox pair. Furthermore, the production rate of H2O2/HO· could be controlled under the assistance of Mn species, and the life of HO· could be enhanced under the assistance of Al species. Under the attack of hydroxyl active radicals (HO·), the phenol are converted into DHB, which include hydroquinone and catechol. In consequence, thanks for the synergic effect of the ternary catalytically active centers (Fe, Al and Mn), the catalytic performance was greatly improved in the case of the catalyst of FAM-MS, with higher selective of DHB. Furthermore, the presence of Al and Mn can improve the hydrothermal stability of MS by improving the thickness of pore walls, this was conducive to recycling of catalysts. 3.5 The recycling tests The recycling tests of catalyst FAM-MS were performed and corresponding results are showed in Fig. 11 . In addition, we adopted a special catalyst circulation method to eliminate the small amount of tar adsorbed on the surface of a catalyst which produced during the reaction process. Detailed operation method was displayed in the experiment section. As shown in Fig. 11 (a), after fifteenth times recycling tests, the resulted catalyst reveals a durable catalytic activity with puny activity-loss (20% conversion & 90% selectivity DHB), demonstrating much better catalytic stability for low-temperature selective catalytic oxidization of phenol with H2O2. In addition, we employed the small-angle XRD to investigate the variation of the mesoporous structure during the recycling test for catalysts FAM-MS, and corresponding spectra are listed in Fig. 11 (b). As showed in Fig. 11 (b), the diffraction peak (100) could be still maintained, which suggested the catalyst FAM-MS possessed mesoporous structure after fifteen recycling tests. In the meantime, to examine the mass loss of the active center of Fe, Al, Mn during the reaction process, we employed the ICP-OES method to monitor it after every five cycles, which is another critical factor for catalyst life. As shown in Table S4, the leaching of the active center (Fe, Al, Mn) does not exceed 8% after fifteenth times recycling tests. These results strongly support that the resultant catalyst possesses durable catalytic activity. Meanwhile, considering this green catalytic reaction process, this catalyst exhibited great industrial application prospect. 4 Conclusions In summary, we successfully synthesised a highly-efficient and durable heterogeneous catalyst FAM-MS by one-pot hydrothermal method. In this catalysts, the tetrahedral coordinated Fe and Mn species were simultaneously introduced into the skeleton of mesoporous silicon dioxide. In additionally, this ternary heterogeneous catalyst could maintain huge SBET (918 m2 g−1), 2D hexagonal mesostructured and narrow pore size distribution (2.71 nm) after introducing metal species. Furthermore, the results catalyst FAM-MS showed a greater catalytic activity (conversion of 22.8% and selectivity of 93.1%) for selective oxidization of high concentration of phenol (ca. 30%) with H2O2 under the room-temperature (25 °C). Meanwhile, the conversion and selectivity of dihydroxybenzene could be maintained above 20% and 90%, respectively, after recovering for 15 cycles. This ternary-component catalyst exhibited great industrial application prospect. coredata.dc:description: Multi-components-bearing mesoporous silica pays the way to the controlling of catalytic selective oxidation by virtue of the synergy of several functional active species in the catalyst, but still faces huge challenge in design and preparation of this functional catalyst. Herein, we rationally constructed a steady ternary-component catalyst (FAM-MS) by incorporating three kinds of catalytically active centers Fe, Al and Mn into the skeleton of mesoporous silica, which reveals a potential industrial application prospect. These resultant catalyst samples were investigated thoroughly by various means, which include XRD, HRTEM, N2-isotherms, UV–vis, and XPS. The present results indicated that the FAM-MS catalyst affords narrow pore size distribution (2.71 nm), 2D hexagonal mesostructure and huge specific surface area (918 m2·g−1) which accordingly contributes to a capacious catalytic reaction space. In addition, the synergy of tri-active components shows greater ability to improve the selectivity of DHB, compared to single-active component and dual-active components ones. As a result, the catalyst FAM-MS shows an optimal catalytic activity (22.8% conversion & 93.1% selectivity DHB) under the optimal reaction conditions for selective oxidization of high concentration of phenol solution (ca. 30%) with H2O2 by virtue of the solubilizing effect of lauryl sodium sulfate in the reaction system. More importantly, the resulted catalyst reveals a durable catalytic activity with puny activity-loss (20% conversion & 90% selectivity DHB) during the fifteen recycling, which exhibits potential industrial application prospect.
coredata.dc:title: Exposed ternary metal active sites on mesoporous channels: A promising catalyst for low-temperature selective catalytic oxidization of phenol with H2O2
